Senna glycoside (Senna)

 Sennosides, croscarmellose sodium, dicalcium phosphate, hypromellose, magnesium stearate, microcrystalline cellulose, mineral oil Stimulant Laxatives 8.6 MG tablet (06/01/2016 - ) Active Take 2 tablets by mouth nightly EMH Burn Unit North
Comment: Senna should not be used in people with dehydration, diarrhea, or loose stools. It can make these conditions worse.

Clotrimazole (LOTRIMIN) 1 % vaginal cream

 benzyl alcohol, cetyl alcohol, cetyl esters wax, octyldodecanol, polysorbate 60, sorbitan monostearate, stearyl alcohol, water Antifungal N/A (06/01/2016 - ) Active Insert 1 mg into the vagina 2 (two) times a day. Wash affected area and dry thoroughly. Apply a thin layer over affected area twice daily (morning and night) supervise children in the use of this product use daily for 4 weeks if condition persists longer, ask a doctor this product is not effective on the scalp or nails EMH Burn Unit North
Comment: This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems.

 Powdered cellulose, magnesium stearate, sodium metabisulfite†, pregelatinized starch (corn), and modified starch (corn). Opioid 300-30 MG per tablet (06/25/2016 - ) Active Take 1 tablet by mouth every 4 (four) hours as needed for moderate pain. Acetaminophen and codeine phosphate tablets are indicated for the relief of mild to moderately severe pain. EMH Burn Unit North
Comment: Codeine may be habit-forming. Patients should take the drug only for as long as it is prescribed, in the amounts prescribed, and no more frequently than prescribed.

NURSING NOTES

Summary Written by: Date
The patient arrived with burns on her pelvis and burns on both upper thighs.

The thigh burns were exacerbated by the wheelchair pad which retained the water and the heat causing the blistering and pain.

Tylenol 3s were administered for pain		 Colon, Wilma 06/18/2016 11:59 AM
▼

HOSPITAL COURSE

Summary Written by: Date
The patient was found to have 2nd degree burns on her pelvis and 3rd degree burns on both upper thighs.

The thigh burns were exacerbated by the wheelchair pad which retained the water and the heat causing the blistering and pain.

The burns were cleaned and dressed.

The burn on the right thigh required skin grafting.

Tylenol 3s were administered for pain		 Bernie Burns, MD 06/18/2016 11:59 AM
